ligent tutoring systems. Handwritten mathematical symbol recognition is an emerging application of computer vision and deep learning that enables machines to interpret human-written notations. Unlike printed text, handwritten symbols vary in style, size, and shape, making traditional OCR techniques less effective. This project aims to develop a CNN-based model capable of recognizing handwritten mathematical operators such as +, −, ×, ÷ and other symbols. Using image preprocessing methods like binarization and adaptive thresholding, the system enhances accuracy and robustness, paving the way for intelligent equation recognition and digitization applications. 1.2 Scope of the Project The scope of this project involves designing and implementing an intelligent deep learning-based system that can accurately recognize handwritten mathematical symbols and operators. The system is designed to process only PNG image inputs for consistency in preprocessing and model compatibility. 4. und noise using morphological operations. ● Contrast Normalization: Adjusted pixel intensity to emphasize handwritten features. 8. Data Augmentation: Applied transformations such as rotation (±10°), translation, and zooming (up to 20%) to increase dataset diversity and mitigate class imbalance. 9. Outcome: The final preprocessed and augmented dataset is diverse, balanced, and standardized, providing a reliable foundation for accurate handwritten mathematical symbol recognition in the MathScribe system. 10 3.1.2 Module 2 (Feature Engineering in detail) This module focuses on transforming unstructured handwritten mathematical symbol images into structured, machine-learnable representations. The operations performed are as follows: 1. Input Standardization ○ All handwritten images are resized to a fixed resolution of 45×45 p ixels to maintain dimensional uniformity. ○ Images are converted to binary format, reducing RGB redundancy and minimizing computational overhead. 2. Binarization and

Noise Removal ○ Adaptive thresholding is applied to convert grayscale images into binary (black and white) format, enhancing symbol edge clarity. ○ Noise filtering techniques such as Gaussian blur and morphological operations are used to eliminate scanning artifacts and unwanted marks. 3. Normalization and Enhancement ○ Pixel intensities are normalized to the [0,1] range for stable gradient propagation during CNN training. ○ Contrast normalization is performed to enhance the visibility of symbol strokes and maintain consistent pixel intensity distribution. 4. Data Augmentation ○ To increase dataset variability and reduce overfitting, augmentation transformations are applied: Rotation: ±15° ○ Translation: up to 10% along X and Y axes ○ Zooming: up to 20% ○ Horizontal flipping: simulates handwriting style variations. 5. Automatic Feature Extraction (CNN-based) ○ The Convolutional Neural Network extracts multi-level spatial features, starting from low-level edges to high-level symbolic st

ructures. ○ These extracted feature maps serve as discriminative representations for the classification model. 6. Outcome ○ The final feature-engineered dataset is highly consistent, noise-free, and information-rich, enabling efficient and accurate recognition of handwritten mathematical symbols and operators within the MathScribe system. 3.1.3 Module 3 (Inference and Web Deployment) This module focuses on implementing the trained model for real-time symbol recognition and integrating it into an interactive web-based user interface for end users. It bridges the gap between model development and real-world usability, allowing handwritten mathematical symbols to be recognized directly through an intuitive web interface. 1. Inference Phase 1. The trained Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model is loaded to perform symbol prediction on unseen input images. 11 2. Input images are preprocessed in real time using the same transformations as the training pipeline including resizing to 45×45 p

ixels, grayscale conversion, and normalization. 3. The processed image is passed through the CNN, which outputs a probability vector across 14 classes representing different mathematical symbols. 4. The class with the highest probability is selected as the predicted symbol, which is then displayed in the output interface. 5. The inference module is optimized for low latency and high accuracy, ensuring real-time feedback for user inputs. 2. Web Deployment Architecture 1. The model is deployed using a Flask backend, which exposes an inference API endpoint for symbol recognition. 2. The frontend interface is designed using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript allowing users to upload or draw handwritten symbols. 3. On submission, the frontend sends the input image to the backend via an HTTP POST request, where it is processed and classified by the trained CNN model. 4. The prediction result is returned to the frontend and displayed instantly, simulating a real-time Mathematical OCR experience. 5. Th

e deployed system can run locally or be hosted on cloud platforms like Google Colab, Render, or Hugging Face Spaces for demonstration purposes. 3. Integration and Performance 1. The inference and web modules are fully integrated, ensuring smooth transition from data input → preprocessing → model prediction → result display. 2. Optimization techniques such as model serialization using .h5 and lightweight model loading were applied to minimize runtime overhead. 3. The deployment UI supports testing multiple symbols, clearing the canvas, and visualizing model outputs for interactive evaluation. 12 Chapter 4 Implementation 4.1 Dataset Details The dataset used in this project is the Handwritten Math Symbols Dataset available on Kaggle (created by xainano). ructure, and suitability for training deep learning models for handwritten symbol recognition.
